channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: October 24
item.description: The Indian Grand Prix will be held on the outskirts of Delhi from Oct. 25 – 27.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Red Bull Formula One driver Sebastian Vettel of Germany, right, walking at the Buddh International Circuit in Greater Noida on the outskirts of Delhi. The Indian Grand Prix will take place from October 25 to 27.

item.title: Ireland Vows to Review Roma Child Welfare Cases
item.description: The government’s move followed the removal of two blond, blue-eyed Roma children from their families, who were returned when DNA tests confirmed their parentage.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: India Ink: India’s Battle Against Nutrition Data Deficiency
item.description: For the past eight years, the government in India has not collected national-level data to gauge the nutritional status of children.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: A child being weighed using a Salter scale during a health camp in Netra village in West Bengal, on July 6.

item.title: North Korea Says It Will Release 6 South Korean Detainees
item.description: The surprise announcement was welcomed in Seoul, though it remained unclear who the six men were.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Letter From Europe: Cloud Is Cast Over Britain’s Institutions
item.description: In Britain, politicians assail the police for conspiring to bring down one of their own, the police accuse the authorities of bullying, and the public trusts neither.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: From left to right, Inspector Ken MacKaill, Sergeant Chris Jones and Detective Sergeant Stuart Hinton arrived at Portcullis House in London on Wednesday to face questions from Parliament. Politicians have assailed the police for a purported conspiracy to bring down the lawmaker Andrew Mitchell.

item.title: Increase in Activity Reported at North Korean Nuclear Test Site
item.description: The U.S.-Korea Institute, which based its conclusion on analysis of satellite images, said there was no sign that another nuclear test was imminent.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Anger Growing Among Allies Over U.S. Surveillance
item.description: In an unusual move between staunch allies, Germany on Thursday called for the United States ambassador after reports that American intelligence had tapped into Chancellor Angela Merkel’s cellphone.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel was assured that the United States was not intercepting her calls.

item.title: India Ink: The Last Jews of Kolkata
item.description: As the Jewish community of Kolkata dwindles, a famed Jewish school embraces Muslim students.
item.dc:creator: By ZACH MARKS
item.media:description: The interior of the Magen David Synagogue in Kolkata, West Bengal.

item.title: Dominicans of Haitian Descent Cast Into Legal Limbo by Court
item.description: The nation’s top court has declared that the children of undocumented Haitian migrants — even those born on Dominican soil decades ago — are no longer entitled to citizenship.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Wine’s Pedigree Faked
item.description: European authorities are pursuing a network of counterfeiters who passed off hundreds of bottles of mediocre wine as Romanée-Conti, often considered the best and most expensive wine in the world.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Drownings Put Migration at Fore of European Meeting
item.description: The question of how to share the burden of the waves of refugees crossing the Mediterranean is dividing the European Union after more than 360 drowned off Sicily this month.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: The bodies of two children were taken to Malta on Oct. 12, a day after a boat filled with migrants sank, killing more than 30.

item.title: Pakistani Premier Meets Obama to Mend Ties
item.description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif visited the White House on Wednesday, seeking to bolster his new civilian government and mend the frayed relationship between his country and the United States.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan in the Oval Office.

item.title: Tunisian Protests, by Islamist and Secular Groups, Delay Talks on Constitution
item.description: Violence in Tunisia, the birthplace of the Arab Spring revolts, has postponed talks that were intended to end a standoff over a new constitution.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: 7-Year Low Reported in Piracy Off Somalia
item.description: The United Nations secretary general attributed the decline to increased international policing and information-sharing, more prosecutions and imprisonment of captured pirates, and greater security steps by commercial shippers.

item.title: Tehran Journal: A Homely Relic on Wheels Awakens Nostalgia in Iran
item.description: The Paykan, once Iran’s national car, is making a comeback, evoking memories of simpler times from the many Iranians who recall riding in it, or pushing it.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Kaveh Kazemi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shahin Armin, a design engineer, with an old Paykan, formerly Iran’s national car, at a gallery in Tehran.

item.title: Left to Languish, Costly Fire Trucks Present a Reminder of Thai Dysfunction
item.description: As millions of dollars in never-used fire equipment decays in a parking lot, justice against two former officials convicted of malfeasance and bid-rigging remains elusive and questions of bribery remain.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Giulio Di Sturco for The New York Times
item.media:description: Never-used fire equipment parked in a lot in Sai Noi, on the outskirts of Bangkok.

item.title: Anger Growing Among Allies on U.S. Spying
item.description: Germany became the latest ally to confront the United States over reports that it was the target of N.S.A. surveillance, after France raised similar concerns.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Criticism of United States’ Mideast Policy Increasingly Comes From Allies
item.description: As America grapples with intractable problems over its policies on Iran and Syria, it has run into a buzz saw of criticism from Israeli and Saudi Arabian leaders.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, on Wednesday in Rome.

item.title: Some Iranians Seek to Renew an Old Chant
item.description: Several hard-line groups have announced plans for a “Down With U.S.A.” conference next month, with an award for the best photograph, poster, video, song or caricature.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: The Lede: Adelson Suggests U.S. Nuclear Strike on Iran Ahead of Negotiations
item.description: Sheldon Adelson, a leading donor to conservative politicians who share his staunch support for Israel, suggested that the United States should begin negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program by launching a nuclear attack on the Iranian desert.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Lawmaker Says Iran Has Halted Enrichment
item.description: Hossein Naqavi Hosseini, a leading Iranian lawmaker, said the country had already stopped enriching uranium up to 20 percent, as it had enough for its reactor in Tehran.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Russia Reduces Charges in Greenpeace Case
item.description: Investigators said the crew members of a Greenpeace ship who staged a protest at an Arctic oil rig would face charges of hooliganism instead of piracy.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: A Royal Christening in Britain Amid a Refrain of Coos
item.description: People waited overnight for a view of Prince George, third in line to the throne, who was dressed in a replica of a lace gown first worn by Queen Victoria’s eldest daughter.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Prince George of Cambridge was dressed in an intricate lace and satin replica of the christening gown made for the eldest daughter of Queen Victoria in 1841.

item.title: U.S. Disputes Reports of Wiretapping in France and Germany
item.description: President Obama spoke with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany about allegations that her personal cellphone was tapped, and another U.S. official denied widespread eavesdropping in France.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Middle East Peace Talks Go On, Under the Radar
item.description: Negotiators for Israel and the Palestinians are adhering to Secretary of State John Kerry’s admonition not to disclose the content of the meetings.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and MICHAEL R. GORDON
